factoid: Princess Mary began to tell Rostóv that all this had happened the day after her father's funeral.
Princess Mary's voice trembled.
Princess Mary turned away.
Princess Mary looked at Rostóv with an apprehensive glance of inquiry because she feared he might take her words as meant to move him to pity.
Rostóv had tears in his eyes.
Princess Mary noticed Rostóv's tears.
Princess Mary glanced gratefully at Rostóv with a radiant look.
Rostóv said he cannot express how glad he is that he happened to ride here and is able to show his readiness to serve Princess Mary.
Rostóv said, "Go when you please, and I give you my word of honor that no one shall dare to cause you annoyance if only you will allow me to act as your escort."
Rostóv bowed respectfully and moved toward the door.
Rostóv's deferential tone indicated that he would consider himself happy to be acquainted with Princess Mary but did not wish to take advantage of her misfortunes to intrude upon her.
Princess Mary understood Rostóv's intent and appreciated his delicacy.
Princess Mary said in French, "I am very, very grateful to you, but I hope it was all a misunderstanding and that no one is to blame for it."
Princess Mary suddenly began to cry.
Princess Mary said, "Excuse me!"
Rostóv knit his brows, left the room with another low bow.
Ilyín saw Rostóv following a different train of thought.
Rostóv glanced angrily at Ilyín and strode off to the village.
Rostóv said to himself, "I'll show them; I'll give it to them, the brigands!"
Alpátych followed Rostóv at a gliding trot.
Rostóv asked, "What decision have you been pleased to come to?"
Rostóv said, "Decision? What decision? Old dotard! What have you been about? The peasants are rioting, and you can't manage them? You're a traitor yourself! I know you. I'll flay you all alive!"
Rostóv left Alpátych and went forward.
Alpátych kept pace with Rostóv and continued to impart his views.
Alpátych said the peasants were obdurate and that it would be imprudent to "overresist" them without an armed force, and that it would be better to send for the military.
Rostóv said, "I'll give them armed force... I'll 'overresist' them!"
Rostóv moved unconsciously with quick steps toward the crowd.
The nearer Rostóv drew to the crowd, the more Alpátych felt the unreasonable action might produce good results.
The peasants were impressed when they saw Rostóv's rapid, firm steps and resolute, frowning face.
After the hussars came to the village and Rostóv had gone to see Princess Mary, confusion and dissension arose among the crowd.
Some peasants said the new arrivals were Russians and might take it amiss that the mistress was being detained.
Dron held the opinion that the new arrivals were Russians.
Karp and others attacked their ex-Elder Dron.
Karp shouted at Dron, "How many years have you been fattening on the commune?"
Karp said, "It's all one to you! You'll dig up your pot of money and take it away with you. What does it matter to you whether our homes are ruined or not?"
Another said, "We've been told to keep order, and that no one is to leave their homes or take away a single grain, and that's all about it!"
A little old man attacked Dron, saying, "It was your son's turn to be conscripted, but no fear! You begrudged your lump of a son."
The little old man said, "And so they took my Vánka to be shaved for a soldier! But we all have to die."
